p: Plants have a long history of antibiotic usage for the cure of disease caused by microorganisms. Many extracts from different plants have been tested for their antimicrobial activities, but there are still many plants requiring more careful investigation to reveal their hidden potential(s). While increasingly difficult socioeconomic situations and unavailability of modern medicine at affordable prices have forced tropical and developing countries, recording high rate of infectious diseases, to rely on traditional medicines [ 36, 37], antimicrobial agents from medicinal plants are increasingly showing their potentials to cure invasive infections [ 38, 39]. Therefore, the acceptance of traditional medicine as an alternative form of health care and the development of microbial resistance to the available antibiotics has led scientists to investigate the antimicrobial activity of medicinal plants [ 40]. The medicinal plants are, thus, recognized as a source of new drugs and complementary medicines, neutraceuticals, pharmaceuticals, and intermediate chemicals for synthetic drugs and their versatile applications [ 41â€“ 43].
